Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolutionary and Comparative Models of the Demographic Transition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Mary Shenk (University of Missouri) and Dr. Mary Towner (Oklahoma State University) will use nested datasets from Matlab, Bangladesh, to examine evolutionary and comparative models of the demographic transition, a global phenomenon in which high fertility and mortality are replaced by low fertility and mortality. Most research links the demographic transition to economic development, but the underlying mechanisms still inspire interdisciplinary debate; as a unifying framework, evolutionary theory shows great potential for helping to clarify both the motivations and mechanisms involved. The goals of the project are to advance theoretical and empirical understanding of the demographic transition using evolutionary theory, and to provide the first comprehensive comparative analyses of key evolutionary and non-evolutionary models. These goals will be met through three specific aims: (1) use large-scale, longitudinal data from Bangladesh to evaluate three influential evolutionary models of the demographic transition, focusing on risk, parental investment, and cultural evolution; (2) use an evidence-based statistical approach to compare evolutionary models with their non-evolutionary counterparts; and (3) collect detailed new data on a subsample of the Matlab population to provide in-depth information to facilitate the comparison of multiple models.

The demographic transition will have significant social impacts in the 21st century. High birthrates hinder economic development in poor nations, while population aging and low fertility undermine safety nets and contribute to social tensions in developed nations. Evolutionary approaches have the potential to revolutionize the study of demographic behavior, yet work in evolutionary demography has been limited in scope and is only familiar to a small community of scholars. This project aims to alter this pattern by testing evolutionary models using population-level data, comparing them to models from other fields, and publishing the results across disciplines. The project will address policy implications by disseminating findings to the study population, policy journals, and the development work community. It will also provide research training to students and forge durable ties between collaborating institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The demographic transition, an ongoing global phenomenon in which high fertility and mortality rates are gradually replaced by low fertility and mortality rates, will have significant long-term impacts on the world in the 21st century. High birthrates slow economic development in less developed nations, while population aging combined with below-replacement fertility undermines social safety nets and contributes to social tensions in more developed nations. The question of why the demographic transition has occurred, or is occurring, in most of the world has inspired decades of interdisciplinary debate. The demographic literature usually links the transition, which became widespread in the 19th and 20th centuries, to the financial, social, and technological changes associated with economic development. Yet the causal mechanisms underlying this relationship are contested, and an improved understanding of them is necessary if we are to effectively shape population policy for both the developing and the developed world.

The goals of our project were to 1) collect detailed new data to augment an existing large, longitudinal dataset, and 2) rigorously evaluate three influential models of the demographic transition. Population-level demographic data came from an existing longitudinal dataset collected by the International Center for Diarrheal Disease Research, Bangladesh (ICDDR,B). Drawn from a complete sample of the population of rural Matlab, Bangladesh, the data cover a period of over forty years during which total fertility rates fell by more than 3.5 children per woman (from 6.8 children to 2.5 children) and mortality rates decreased by 50-70%. We augmented this with data collected on a subsample of the Matlab study population.  This included (a) 52 open-ended interviews on fertility, parental investment, and social and economic change used for theme analysis as well as context and interpretation, and (b) a survey of 944 women including detailed family and individual level information on fertility, parental investment, residence, marriage, occupation, income, and labor migration. Each survey and interview was linked to the demographic data in the full sample.

Our main analysis compared major models of fertility decline to determine which produced the best explanation of the recent demographic transition in Matlab, Bangladesh.  The literature is crowded with competing theories, including causal models that emphasize the roles of (a) mortality and extrinsic risk, (b) the economic costs and benefits of investing in self and children in modern market economies, and (c) the cultural transmission of low-fertility social norms. Using detailed demographic data from our 2010 fieldwork, we rigorously compared models using an evidence-based statistical approach employing model selection techniques derived from likelihood theory. This approach allows us to quantify and compare the relative evidence the data give to alternative models, even when model predictions are not mutually exclusive.

Our key finding, published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (Shenk et al. 2013b) and favorably discussed in a commentary in Nature (Mace 2013), is that fertility, measured as either as the number of children born or the number of children surviving, is best explained by economic change and related motivations for investment in children or self. Our results also suggest important synergies between models, implicating multiple causal pathways in the speed and degree of recent demographic transitions.
